Jon Zelner `jzelner@umich.edu` [`epibayes.io`](https://epibayes.io)

![](../images/epid_logo.png){.absolute bottom=0 right=50 width="440" height="100"} ## Agenda - Discussing Subramanian et al. paper [@subramanian2005a] - Hands-on with some multi-level models. ## Discussion Questions 1. What is the goal of the hierarchical modeling exercise in Subramanian et al.[@subramanian2005a] 2. What is learned from the inclusion of multiple levels of scale (i.e. block group, census tract) in this analysis? 3. What do you think 1-2 important takeaways are from reading this analysis? Use [this document](https://docs.google.com/document/d/1y8GsRLdW13IhckMF_3K4PHdHPy-eY46bzemKiaJOO6Y/edit?usp=sharing) to share your conclusions ## Area-level covariates explained more spatial variation in mortality for Black vs. White residents {.imgslide} ![](../images/subramanian_table_4.png) Table 4 from [@subramanian2005a] ## Capturing systematic and random variation with multi-level models {.imgslide} ![](../images/hierarchical_hands_on.png) Time to [generate some data](https://sph-umich.shinyapps.io/hierarchical_models) ## Next Time {.imgslide} ![](../images/creature_from_the_black_lagoon_franchise_retrospective.jpg) The [Modifiable Areal Unit Problem!](https://publish.obsidian.md/epibayes/Courses/EPID684/modules/Module+5/What+do+you+measure+when+you+measure+place+effects%3F+Confronting+the+modifiable+areal+unit+problem.html) ## References
